natural problem: Expand $-(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$. What is the sum of the coefficients of the expanded form?
natural solution: Simplifying the term $(c+2(3-c))$ gives $c+6-2c=6-c$. Distributing the negative sign over the first term gives $-(3-c)=c-3$.
So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. f c = -(3-c)*(c+2*(3-c))"
shows  "coeffs (f c) = -10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Simplifying the term $(c+2(3-c))$ gives $c+6-2c=6-c$. Distributing the negative sign over the first term gives $-(3-c)=c-3$.
 So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. f c = -(3-c)*(c+2*(3-c))"
shows  "coeffs (f c) = -10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the coefficient of the function $f(c)$ defined as $f(c) = -(3-c)*(c+2*(3-c))$. The final answer is $-10$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
and h1 : "P c = a * c powr 2 + b * c + d"
shows  "a + b + d = -10"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.
 *)

assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
and h1 : "P c = a * c powr 2 + b * c + d"
shows  "a + b + d = -10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real
defines P_def : "P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
shows  "P c = c powr 2 - 4*c - 6" and "sum_coeffs (P c) = -10"
where "sum_coeffs p = (\<Sum>n. coeff p n)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand $-(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$. What is the sum of the coefficients of the expanded form? The final Answer is -10
 ### Proof
 Simplifying the term $(c+2(3-c))$ gives $c+6-2c=6-c$. Distributing the negative sign over the first term gives $-(3-c)=c-3$.
 So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: real
defines P_def : "P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
shows  "P c = c powr 2 - 4*c - 6" and "sum_coeffs (P c) = -10"
where "sum_coeffs p = (\<Sum>n. coeff p n)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given the function $P(c) = -(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$, find a simplified expression for $P(c)$. Show that $P(c) = c^2 - 4c - 6$ and that the sum of the coefficients of the simplified expression is $-10$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. P c = -c powr 2 + 4 * c - 6"
shows  "sum_coefficients P = -10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand $-(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$. What is the sum of the coefficients of the expanded form? The final Answer is -10
 ### Proof
 Simplifying the term $(c+2(3-c))$ gives $c+6-2c=6-c$. Distributing the negative sign over the first term gives $-(3-c)=c-3$.
 So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.
 *)

and h1 : "\<forall> c. P c = -c powr 2 + 4 * c - 6"
shows  "sum_coefficients P = -10"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. Q c = -10"
and h2 : "\<forall> c. P c = Q c"
shows  "sum_of_coeffs (P c) = sum_of_coeffs (Q c)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Expand $-(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$. What is the sum of the coefficients of the expanded form? The final Answer is -10
 ### Proof
 Simplifying the term $(c+2(3-c))$ gives $c+6-2c=6-c$. Distributing the negative sign over the first term gives $-(3-c)=c-3$.
 So our product is $$(c-3)(6-c)=6c-c^2-18+3c=-c^2+9c-18.$$ The sum of the coefficients is $(-1)+(9)+(-18)=\boxed{-10}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> c. P c = -(3 - c) * (c + 2 * (3 - c))"
and h1 : "\<forall> c. Q c = -10"
and h2 : "\<forall> c. P c = Q c"
shows  "sum_of_coeffs (P c) = sum_of_coeffs (Q c)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a polynomial function $P(c) = -(3 - c)(c + 2(3 - c))$ and a constant function $Q(c) = -10$. If $P(c) = Q(c)$ for all $c$, find the sum of the coefficients of $P(c)$ and compare it to the sum of the coefficients of $Q(c)$.

 *)

fixes c :: real
defines p: "p c = -(3-c) * (c + 2*(3-c))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{0..2}. coeff (p c) i) = -10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of the coefficients of the polynomial $p(c) = -(3-c)(c+2(3-c))$. The final answer is -10.
